channel.title: Home on Aleksi Tarvainen
channel.description: Recent content in Home on Aleksi Tarvainen

item.title: M.net listings aggregator
item.description: Goal At some point this summer I noticed that I spend too much time browsing through listings on Muusikoiden.net’s tori (a Finnish marketplace for used music gear). Of course, as a programmer the first thing that comes to mind is automate things, so I did. The goal was to develop a program that scrapes new listings from the site and sends a daily summary of them via email. Development process I started by looking at what web scraping libraries were available for Haskell.

item.title: Chargen
item.description: I built this OSRIC‚Ñ¢ compatible random character generator, not because there isn’t one or another already, but because none of them is my own üòÅ. It is a bit limited right now, because it only generates characters' attributes, alignments, class-race combinations and randomized levels. Maybe I will extend it by making generation of names, items, small descriptions and such possible in the future. I wrote the back-end in Haskell and front-end in Elm, which both are functional programming languages.

item.title: A December of Algorithms 2019
item.description: What? A December of Algorithms 2019 was an open coding challenge organized by SVCE-ACM student chapter. For each day of the month they presented a small algorithmic programming problem. Solutions to all of the problems had to be submitted by 2020-01-10. Why? The holidays were approaching and I thought I’d need something to keep my little gray programming brain cells active. I was aware of Advent of Code, but I decided to do this challenge instead, because I considered it to be more approachable and doable, for sure.

item.title: Vaalikartta
item.description: Vaalikartta is a web app to explore data about Finnish parliamentary elections from 1983 to 2019. It also includes some information about each municipality and cabinets. It is a product of the course Open Data Student Projects (TIEA207). We developed the app in a group of four students. I took care of extracting most of the data and developing the back-end API. We didn’t have any designated project manager, but our project board was managed mostly by me.

item.title: Homepage
item.description: I started working on this site on 2019-09-04. The site is built with Hugo using its various functionalities (e.g. templates). The theme is my home brew. I call it minimus for being minimal (although bare-bones would describe it equally well). As a side note, Hugo is based on the Go programming language, which I haven’t particularly used at all, but it seemed the best alternative of the static site generators I know of (Jekyll, Hakyll, Gatsby.

item.title: RPG-Dice
item.description: I built this little app, when I was working on Helsinki university’s Fullstack MOOC 2019. I wanted to try out how Typescript pairs with React. Maybe Typescripts best parts wont’t show, when making such small apps, but I saw it’s potential. Defining types gives me a sense of safety and I much prefer compilation errors to runtime errors, which really don’t hint at eg. what could cause something to be undefined.

item.title: About me
item.description: About me I’m a fifth-year student at University of Jyv√§skyl√§ majoring in mathematical information technology. I’m driven about doing robust and maintainable code - building software that matters. That has lead me to explore topics like functional programming and best practices of software development. Regarding my musical endeavors, I’m part of the band This Horse. I dabble with making music solo (too), but I haven’t dared to put out anything yet.
